text:
regarding the introduction of the new navigation
With the new navigation, I was unable add a new email setting in the domain manager
overlay background appeared but no data to continue. I tried 3 different browsers. Needed to swicth back to add a new email sending domain.

I’ve been banging my head against the wall over this problem:
I have a blog listing that has a featured post at the top then 9 posts underneath.
The way that the listing is designed I need specific iterations of the loop to occupy specific containers, so the code looks like this:
`{% for content in contents %}`
 `       {% if loop.index == 1 || loop.index == 6 || loop.index == 7 %}`
`              // post style 1 //`
`       {% elif loop.index == 2 || loop.index == 4 || loop.index == 8 %}`
`              // post style 2 //`
`       {% elif loop.index == 3 || loop.index == 5 || loop.index == 9 %}`
`              // post style 3 //`
`       {% endif %}`
`{% endfor %}`
So I can take the post out of the loop using _unless_ but that breaks the layout by leaving an empty space. Is there a way to filter the content loop beforehand and still end up with the correct amount of posts?

Has anyone developed a good way for designers to be able to post inline SVGs into a custom module? We have a 2 column row module that has rich text for each column, but when I put inline SVG into a rich text, it comments out the styles inside the style tag (not sure if that’s intended behavior?)
<@U38EZFVFE> uploaded a file: <https://HubSpotdev.slack.com/files/U38EZFVFE/FAESZJSNR/-.js|Untitled>
<@U5BGUA4BX> You can use Text fields in the DM2
A file was commented on

Hm, good thought <@U38EZFVFE> - Most of the time the module should be rich text, but with this site having so many inline SVGs, I’ll probably add a boolean for “is_column_svg” and toggle visibility of the text vs. rich text editor with that to keep it clean. thanks!
A file was commented on
A file was commented on
Yeah. I used the Text field for that and it works great. Hiding and showing it should be easy in the new editor.
A file was commented on
Curious everyone's thought about the possible impact of building landing pages on a clients website (non HS) and only embedding the form (as well as the tracking code)
if you are trying to get it to rank, it's definitely better to use their primary domain.

So it is more or less work that I don't want to do. Building confirmation pages in HS is tedious. You have two options. Remake their menu and bring over all styles or ajax call to the website after setting up a url to bring in all the css / code
This client is SUPER security minded so me opening up a CORS request isn't going to be easy to happen.  So I don't want to recreate each of these menus in HS, that is so painful
they have 100 data centers
yeah, it's too bad HTML Imports never took off

And this list is going to change it is isn't efficient to do it this way.  I can't think of any reasons that not having the landing and confirmation pages in HS would affect it (I see a plus in ranking, but I'd say most landing pages like this are more of a cta > lp as they are a direct offer(bofu) vs something someone would search for.
<@U7V9DQ31P> <https://gist.github.com/NickDeckerDevs/69c63f649863323f7c04f3b940119b6f>
<@U25PYL3Q8> shared a file: <https://HubSpotdev.slack.com/files/U25PYL3Q8/FAEJCJ5DJ/gistfile1.txt|gistfile1.txt>
that is some documentaiton I have on bringing a wordpress menu into a HubSpot site..
I haven't formatted this so it might be messy, I just pasted from a google doc
nice - that's about the only way to not have to manage two menus
lol and when it isn't working and that error comes up in the header or footer the client is always FREAKING OUT
I should really change that
or use coded HubSpot templates and more or less use the same markup on both sites. then it's just a matter of copying and pasting any time there is an update
the benefit to doing it this way is also only needing 1 stylesheet to work in/maintain
you can bring the stylesheet in when you are exposing the menu, or you can load it from the landing page itself
you can bring the whole header / footer over if you feel like it
y0ou can get pretty creative with it
I've been thinking of ways to make it faster and I thought about the wordpress API and serving the menu like that but I think that would be more work in the long run..not sure
Yeah anything loaded via ajax will take slightly longer. This reminds me of a CMS i once used that loaded the menu via javascript.
